doc.title: US Telecom Services and Infrastructure
doc.source_uri: 2025-09-02/Assuming coverage_ Buy T, TMUS, VZ; Sell CHTR, ATUS_2025-09-02

passages.text: We assume coverage of US Telecom and Cable (8 stocks) including AT&T (T, Buy), T- Mobile (TMUS, Buy), Verizon (VZ, Buy), Charter (CHTR, Sell), Altice (ATUS, Sell), Cogent (CCOI, Neutral), Lumen (LUMN, Neutral), and Frontier (FYBR, Not Rated). We expect 2026 will likely be a pivotal year for the US telecom and cable sectors given heightened competition in consumer connectivity services (i.e., wireless and wireline). Unlike in years past where competitive responses were largely through plan pricing and wireless handset promotions, we are seeing more competitive activity through wireless and wireline bundling ("convergence"), network leadership & modernization efforts, and price- value offerings including third party services (e.g., streaming, AI).

Our Buy ratings on AT&T (T) and T- Mobile (TMUS) reflect our view that their investments in network modernization, spectrum, and brand will help drive the most attractive financial returns including industry leading (1) EBITDA growth; (2) free cash flow conversion; and (3) shareholder capital returns - which justify their premium EV/EBITDA valuation multiples. Our Buy rating on Verizon (VZ) is out- of- consensus, in our view; despite some tactical caution related to 3Q25E phone net additions, our positive view reflects upside to consumer wireless service revenue on waning promotional amortization headwinds and Perks contributing \(\sim 100\) bps to growth, as well the potential for better- than- expected cost & revenue synergies from the proposed acquisition of Frontier, all of which should culminate into increased shareholder capital returns through buybacks in the next 2 years (context: Verizon hasn't done any share repurchases since 2015).

Goldman Sachs does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. We assume coverage of US Telecom and Cable (8 stocks) including AT&T (T, Buy), T- Mobile (TMUS, Buy), Verizon (VZ, Buy), Charter (CHTR, Sell), Altice (ATUS, Sell), Cogent (CCOI, Neutel, Lumen (LUMN, Neutral), and Frontier (FYBR, Not Rated). We expect 2026 will likely be a pivotal year for the US telecom and cable sectors given heightened competition in consumer connectivity services (i.e., wireless and wireline). Unlike in years past where competitive responses were largely through plan pricing and wireless handset promotions, we are seeing more competitive activity through wireless and wireline bundling ("convergence"), network leadership & modernization efforts, and price- value offerings including third party services (e.g., streaming, AI).

Our Buy ratings on AT&T (T) and T- Mobile (TMUS) reflect our view that their investments in network modernization, spectrum, and brand will help drive the most attractive financial returns including industry leading (1) EBITDA growth; (2) free cash flow conversion; and (3) shareholder capital returns - which justify their premium EV/EBITDA valuation multiples. Our Buy rating on Verizon (VZ) is out- of- consensus, in our view; despite some tactical caution related to 3Q25E phone net additions, our positive view reflects upside to consumer wireless service revenue on waning promotional amortization headwinds and Perks contributing \(\sim 100\) bps to growth, as well the potential for better- than- expected cost & revenue synergies from the proposed acquisition of Frontier, all of which should culminate into increased shareholder capital returns through buybacks in the next 2 years (context: Verizon hasn't done any share repurchases since 2015).

Mobile and wireline convergence is accelerating. US telecom companies are accelerating their fiber passings organically, through joint ventures (e.g., AT&T's Gigapower (BlackRock), T- Mobile's Metronet (KKR), Lumos (EQT)), or M&A (e.g., AT&T's proposed acquisition of Lumen Mass Markets, Verizon's proposed acquisition of Frontier). We estimate that from 2024- 2029E, there will be \(55+\) mn additional US fiber passings, providing a growth driver to the fiber revenues of US telcos, as well as expanding the available footprint for a converged offering, thereby improving the LTV and margins of wireless service revenue through lower churn. Unlike past offerings of convergence, we believe the US wireless and broadband bundle differs in that (a) this is a bundle of two highly demanded services, whereas converged offerings in the past usually included a lower relevant offering (e.g., POTS + broadband, video + broadband, video + mobile); (b) the value- add for consumers is a combination of a discount - as well as new product offerings only enabled by single service provider for broadband and mobile (e.g., mobile service as home internet wireless backup; and (c) broadband and wireless companies are making deeper in- roads to become a platform for additional services (e.g., streaming video, music, discounts).

Cable and telco to become the services marketplace. Against the backdrop of slowing volume growth as wireline and wireless subscriptions approach full penetration, the providers have been offering a growing number of plans with price locks (e.g., 5- year price lock guarantee for select plans from CMCSA Xfinity, VZ Fios,

TMUS Experience, 3- year price lock for CHTR Spectrum). As a result, we believe that ARPU growth will become more reliant on plan migrations to premium tiers (i.e., mix), as well as contributions from services marketplaces. Among the telcos, Verizon has been leaning into the marketplace model with Perks, which is a \(\) 2\$ bn annual run- rate business with mid \(30\%\) margins. Notably, Verizon's Perks partnerships are telco exclusives, providing it with a near- to mid- term advantage in ARPU growth as Perks revenue grows. Charter is offering a bundle of free ad- supported streaming services (e.g., AMC+, Disney+, HBO Max, Paramount+, Peacock, Hulu, ESPN unlimited) for its video subscribers with upgrades to ad- free and the sale of these services to its broadband- only subscribers likely accretive to ARPU growth. We believe that the growing reliance by US Media companies on wholesale partnerships to drive streaming video subscriber growth, as well as the potential growth in demand for mobile AI apps and services (e.g., Google Gemini distributed through Verizon as a Perk) creates an opportunity for the wireless carriers to be a competitor to the Apple App Store and Google Play Store as the marketplace for paid apps. Beyond third- party services, we see ARPU growth opportunities through the sale of a- la- carte value- added services including data boosts (e.g., AT&T Turbo), wireless back- up, and satellite services (e.g., T- Satellite).

Growing network traffic and AI to separate winners and losers in network infrastructure. The consumer experience among each of the major wireless carriers (and as a result, their MVNO customers) are of comparable high quality with select areas of geographic outperformance depending on the carrier. That said, the next several years should see growth in network traffic that could make differences in network quality more apparent. First, based on our channel checks, we see network quality advantages accruing to (1) T- Mobile, given its significant holdings of mid- band spectrum; and (2) AT&T, reflecting its industry- leading capital investment ( \(23 - 24 bn annually in 2026- 2027) and network infrastructure (e.g., 60 mn homes passed with fiber by 2030E). In addition, AT&T and cable's (Comcast and Charter) leading wireline footprints should position them well to support tower backhaul, as well as enable those services for convergence revenue. Second, with recent legislation that restored the FCC's spectrum authority and mandated the auction of 800 MHz of spectrum within 8 years (with the first identification deadline in July 2027), we'd expect the US telecom companies will likely set aside capital for spectrum license expenditures over the next several years. Third, we believe that growing adoption of AI services and connected devices (e.g., dedicated consumer hardware for AI, Apple AI home initiatives) should be key drivers of network traffic, although we acknowledge that 5G/IOT drivers in the past have been underwhelming.
We provide a brief overview of our Buy- rated ideas below:

AT&T (T, Buy, \(32 12- month target price, 14\% total return): AT&T should realize a 9\% FCF CAGR (2024- 2029E, ex DTV), which will enable accelerating shareholder capital returns through growing share repurchases (GSe 2025E/26E/27E:\) 4/6/10 bn). (1) Mobility EBITDA should realize sustained 3- 4\% yoy growth through 2029E driven by improved consumer resonance following its continued brand transformation (e.g., AT&T Guarantee) and convergence offerings (e.g., Internet

Backup for customers of both wireless and fiber). (2) Fiber passings are accelerating from 2.4 mn in 2024 to 4 mn annually exiting 2026E (5 mn pro- forma for the proposed acquisition of Lumen Mass Markets), which should help drive continued broadband revenue growth and support a \(13\%\) Consumer Wireline EBITDA CAGR (2024- 2029E) and wireless convergence (i.e., improved LTV and churn). (3) Business Wireline EBITDA declines should improve over time reflecting declining legacy wireline pressures, fiber revenue growth, and cost management including copper decommissioning. (4) AT&T leads the telecom industry in capital investment with \(23 - 24\) bn of annual capital investment in 2026/27 with the acceleration in fiber deployments being funded in part by declining investments in wireless following the completion of modernization efforts. AT&T investments in the network provides it with the largest fiber footprint (2030E: 60 mn homes passed, pro- forma for Lumen) and strong positioning to accommodate growth in network traffic over the coming years as a result of Al. We are Buy rated on T with a 12- month target price of \(32\) reflecting 7X NTM+1Y EBITDA.

Verizon (VZ, Buy \(49\) 12- month target price, \(18\%\) total return): Although we see a tactical speedbump with our 3Q25E Consumer retail postpaid phone net losses estimate of - 47k below consensus of \(+7k\) (Visible Alpha), Verizon should realize accelerating wireless service revenue growth (GSe: \(2.5\%\) 2024- 2029E) from 2025E (+2.2%). We're encouraged by Verizon's investments in fiber, including the proposed acquisition of Frontier, and see the potential for share repurchases in 2027E given strong free cash flow generation, tax reform benefits, and better- than- expected merger synergies. (1) Consumer wireless postpaid phone ARPU should accelerate to \(2\%\) yoy in 2026E (v. \(1\%\) in 2025E) reflecting subsiding contra- revenue headwinds from promotional amortization ( \(\sim 200\) bps headwind to wireless service revenue in 2025E) and continued growth in Perks (\ \(2 bn of annualized revenue run- rate by 2025 year- end). (2) Fios fiber passings growth should grow to 35- 40 mn over time (30 mn by 2028E) from 26 mn pro- forma 2024, which should stabilize consumer Fios revenues (fiber offsetting declines in video and voice). The proposed acquisition of Frontier could provide better- than- expected synergies than Verizon guided to (\) 500 mn cost synergies by year 3) reflecting (a) tax reform benefits ( \(200 - 300\) mn cash tax savings or \(\sim 10\%\) of capex); (b) debt refinancing synergies; and (c) revenue synergies from increasing Verizon's wireless penetration in Frontier's 10 mn 2026E fiber passings footprint ( \(\sim 20\%\) share in Frontier markets v. \(\sim 33\%\) Verizon's national postpaid phone market share), as well increasing fiber penetration ( \(31\%\) in 2Q25 v. \(40\%\) for Fios) through the cross- selling of fiber broadband in Verizon stores. (3) Verizon should be able to deliver by 0.2- 0.3X within \(\sim 1\) year following the proposed acquisition of Frontier, helped by incremental cash tax savings from tax reform, setting Verizon up to deliver \(2.5 / 5.0\) bn of share repurchases in 2027/28E. We are Buy rated on VZ with a 12- month target price of \(49\) reflecting 6.5X NTM+1Y EBITDA.

T- Mobile (TMUS, Buy, \(286\) 12- month target price, \(16\%\) total return): T- Mobile should generate industry- leading EBITDA growth ( \(7\%\) CAGR 2024- 2029E), along with the highest free cash flow conversion ( \(51\%\) FCF: EBITDA in 2025E) among its peer set. Although we expect T- Mobile to continue to lead the industry in postpaid

phone net additions (2- 3 mn per year), we see its historical competitive points of differentiation beginning to wane as T- Mobile transitions from the "Un- carrier" addressing consumer pain points to becoming an industry leader and as its competitors adopt more consumer friendly and brand initiatives in response to share losses. (1) T- Mobile will continue to lead the industry in postpaid phone net additions reflecting its lowest cost/line (postpaid phone ARPUs are \(5 - 510\) lower than AT&T and Verizon), largest number of service inclusions (e.g., T- Satellite, Netflix, Apple TV+), and most aggressive promotions in the market (2- year device promotion earnouts, free lines, competitor contract buyouts). (2) Fixed wireless access and fiber partnerships to improve TMUS penetration into home internet. TMUS will have 8 mn FWA subscribers by 2025E, which we forecast to grow to 13 mn by 2029E (target: 12 mn by 2028E). In addition, its fiber joint ventures (e.g., Metronet, Lumos) will help it increase its fiber passings from 0 in 2024 to 13 mn by 2029E (target: 12- 15 mn by 2030E). That said, TMUS will have the smallest fiber footprint among peers, making it more reliant on FWA to the extent converged offerings (home internet+mobile) become a point of competitive differentiation. (3) T- Mobile has leading EBITDA margins and FCF conversion, which helps to support growing shareholder capital returns. We forecast \(20 bn of shareholder capital returns in 2026E (v.\) 14 bn in 2025E) including \(16 bn in share repurchases and\) 4 bn in dividends. Despite TMUS' industry- leading shareholder capital returns, we see continued capital flexibility with net leverage in 2026/27 still below TMUS' target of 2.5X. We are Buy rated on TMUS with a 12- month target price of \(286 reflecting 10.5X NTM+1Y EBITDA.\)
We provide a brief overview of our Sell- rated ideas below:

Charter Communications (CHTR, Sell, \(223 12- month target price, - 15\%\) total return): Charter's fundamentals likely will remain pressured reflecting competitive pressures from fixed wireless access and fiber. That said, we're encouraged by Charter's efforts in video by providing additional value to its subscribers through access to several video streaming services ( \(100 retail value for no additional cost) and forming the foundation of a digital marketplace for video customers to upgrade to ad- free services or for broadband- only customers to subscribe to these services. Charter's wireless strategy of offering attractively priced wireless plans as a customer acquisition and retention tool should help to mitigate the aforementioned competitive challenges in broadband. Free cash flow conversion should improve over time as capex declines to\) 8 bn in 2028E (v. \(11 bn in 2025E) following the completion of CHTR's rural expansion efforts. Nonetheless, we view the current fundamental challenges more than offsetting what appears to be an attractive valuation when looking on out period 2028E estimates. We are Sell rated on CHTR with a 12- month target price of\) 223 reflecting 5.5X NTM+1Y EBITDA.

Altice USA (ATUS, Sell, \(2.00 12- month target price, - 15\%\) total return): Altice faces the same competitive pressures as its cable peers from fixed wireless access and fiber. The company hasn't realized positive broadband net addition growth since 2020. In addition, ATUS trades at a valuation premium at nearly 8X NTM EV/EBITDA v. cable peers - CMCSA and CHTR - trading at \(\sim 5 - 6X\) . This reflects ATUS high net

leverage (7.8X L2Q annualized) and - in our view - market expectations that ATUS likely will reduce its leverage through a debt exchange or tender below par. We believe that ATUS' high financial leverage and more limited free cash flow reduces its operational flexibility. We are Sell rated on ATUS with a 12-month target price of \(\) 2.00\(reflecting 7.5X NTM + 1Y EBITDA.\)

We initiate with a Neutral-rating on Lumen Technologies (LUMN, 12-month target price of \(\) 4.10\(and Cogent Communications (CCOI, 12 - month target price of\) \ \(40\) ). We are Not Rated on Frontier (FYBR).

US residential broadband subscriptions are approaching full penetration, resulting in a slowdown in growth to \(1 - 2\%\) per annum. Cable broadband technology is the market leader with about \(62\%\) share of subscribers, but should lose share to fiber, which is benefiting from growing availability with fiber passings increasing by at least 55 million from 2024- 2029E, as well as its perception of being a higher quality and more reliable technology. Fixed wireless access continues to be a threat, but is likely more of a transitional technology with competitive intensity and its pace of subscriber net additions waning. The US wireless carriers all have relatively strong spectrum portfolios, with our channel checks suggesting that T- Mobile is better positioned in spectrum over the long- term. The need for continued investment into spectrum assets ahead of 6G and growing customer data requirements will likely lead to US wireless carriers preferring to maintain some financial flexibility for spectrum license purchases over the next several years, particularly given the FCC's recently renewed spectrum auction authority.

US industry broadband subscribers continue to grow. With approximately 122 mn US residential broadband households in the United States, penetration of occupied households is near saturation ( \(\sim 93\%\) ), but should continue to grow - albeit at a modest \(1 - 2\%\) rate - as efforts to close the digital divide through increasing fiber/cable passings and the availability of fixed wireless and satellite broadband become more prevalent (Exhibit 3). Cable broadband is the market leader with 76 mn subscribers ( \(62\%\) share, Exhibit 4), though that likely will decline to 70 mn ( \(52\%\) share) by 2030. Within the 3 major technology types - cable, fiber, and fixed wireless - market share is concentrated, with the top 3 operators in each market controlling about \(80\%\) market share by subscribers (Exhibit 5, Exhibit 6, Exhibit 7).

Fiber subscriber growth to be driven by passings growth across key players. Over the past several years, the industry has begun to see a resurgence in buildout of fiber optic infrastructure targeting future residential and business broadband subscribers following a period of relative inactivity. We believe this resurgence in fiber builds has been driven by: (1) larger telecoms seeking to protect declines in their legacy wireline

subscriber base by upgrading copper infrastructure (e.g., AT&T, Frontier); (2) relatively cheap capital; (3) an uptick in private infrastructure funds providing funding for smaller regional players dedicated to fiber broadband.
Based on a bottom- up analysis of 12 companies, whose fiber passings we track, we see the potential for 55 mn additional fiber passings from 2024- 2029E from these companies alone (Exhibit 11).

- AT&T has a goal to reach \(50+\) million fiber passings by the end of 2029 (60 mn by 2030, pro-forma for the proposed acquisition of Lumen's consumer fiber-to-the-home business). Of the \(50+\) million fiber passings by the end of 2029, 45 million represents fiber passings in AT&T's current footprint, while the remaining \(5+\) million represents Gigapower and other joint ventures. The 60 million fiber passing target for 2030 is not broken down by AT&T current footprint versus joint venture passings.

- Verizon has a goal of reaching 30 million fiber passings by 2028 (pro-forma for the proposed acquisition of Frontier) and 35-40 million over time. At the end of 2024, Verizon had approximately 18 mn homes passed with fiber. Frontier has a started target to reach 10 mn homes passed with fiber by the end of 2026. Verizon expects to have 27-28 million fiber passings at the time of deal closing (1Q26E expectation by Verizon).
- T-Mobile has a goal to reach 12-15 million fiber passings by 2030 (12 million by 2028), when combined with its fiber partnerships.
Exhibit 10: As of 2024, 76.5 mn US homes (56.5%) were passed with fiber, with 88 mn fiber passings (including double passings) US fiber passings, including double passings by provider type (mn)

Fiber is the preferred broadband technology of choice, taking share during churn opportunities. In markets where fiber is available, it tends to be a share gainer. Fiber internet is generally considered better than cable internet reflecting its faster speeds and better reliability (passive optical networks versus cable's active equipment), albeit at higher prices. First, based on a study commissioned by the Fiber Broadband Association, fiber tends to be the broadband technology of choice for new customers, as well as customers that are churning off other types of broadband technology.

Notably, it appears that cable (hybrid fiber coaxial) and DSL (digital subscriber line, which uses copper) are the primary share donors to fiber (Exhibit 12). Second, cable's competitive response will likely continue to be through pricing with the price gap between fiber and cable broadband widening to nearly \(\) 17\$ /month (Exhibit 13), though we recognize that may be partly due to mix with fiber's ability to support faster speeds. For instance, cable companies are likely to increase their focus on driving "converged revenue," the combination of broadband and wireless, with faster growth in wireless revenue (a relatively new and growing revenue stream for cable companies) likely to mitigate the slowing growth in broadband. Notably, Comcast unveiled new pricing and packaging in early 2025 that provided very attractive pricing on broadband, while also including a free wireless line for 1- year which will eventually reprice higher (e.g., \(\) 55\$ /month for 400 Mbps internet with an unlimited line for 1- year, and a 5- year price lock).

Fiber broadband passings are being targeted at cable. Given fiber's competitive advantage relative to cable, it's no surprise that Verizon and AT&T are targeting the cable broadband providers in their expansion plans. In fact, based on our analysis of zipcode and county level subscriber data, we found no overlap in subscribers between Verizon and AT&T (Exhibit 14). The major cable providers - Charter (Spectrum), Comcast (Xfinity), and Cox - compete with fiber in \(55\% - 75\%\) of its zipcode- defined markets - though we recognize that fiber passings occur at a more granular geographic level than zipcodes.

Although broadband competition is already intense, we believe that switching activity would be even higher, if not for low residential housing move activity - which can be a catalyst for switching broadband providers. One proxy of move activity is US existing home sales, which is near cyclical lows (e.g., July 2025 US Existing- home sales were at a 4.01 million seasonally adjusted annual rate versus the monthly average of 5.22 million since January 2000).

Increased move activity should be positive for fiber and fixed wireless given that those technology types have historically been share gainers. We think that move activity should be neutral to negative for cable given that it should gain share from DSL (\\~9 million industry- wide US subscribers at the end of 2024), but lose share to fixed wireless and fiber (Exhibit 12). In our view, growing fiber passings & competition could make move activity incrementally more negative for the incumbent cable broadband, but acknowledge that cable's efforts to improve its product offering (e.g., wireless convergence, network upgrades) could change cable's competitive positioning for the

technology. When it comes to network quality, Verizon has historically held a dominant position, with AT&T showing a consistent strong position. T-Mobile has emerged as a leader in recent years, particularly given its lead in 5G. Currently, all 3 national wireless carriers have scaled, capable networks, but T-Mobile's mid- band spectrum holdings appear to provide a long- term competitive advantage, which may become more apparent over time, based on our channel checks.

The three major US wireless carriers have substantial spectrum positions to support nationwide coverage, but have notable differences in their spectrum holdings as a result of differing strategies and incumbent positions (Exhibit 20). T-Mobile's merger with Sprint in April 2020 brought it mid- band spectrum (2.5 Ghz) that has over time, provided TMUS capacity advantages in 5G. Verizon has invested substantially in upper mid- band and high- band spectrum, including mmWave spectrum for denser urban areas (e.g., Verizon's fixed wireless access for multi- dwelling units). AT&T, like Verizon, spent substantially in C- band to acquire mid- band spectrum, but C- band deployment faced several delays, particularly in the 2020- 21 period, given interference concerns with the FAA.

Although the FCC's general authority to conduct spectrum auctions lapsed on March 9, 2023, that authority was restored on July 4, 2025 when the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) was signed into law. OBBBA restores the FCC's general authority to auction spectrum through September 30, 2034. The bill excludes the lower 3Ghz band (3.1- 3.45 GHz), which based on our channel checks was the most desirable band among commercial users but is currently occupied by government agencies, including the Department of Defense for shipborne and airborne radar systems supporting missile defense, airborne early warning and control, aerial surveillance, and other functions. The bill also excludes frequencies in the 7.4- 8.4 GHz band.

OBBBA requires the auction of \(\sim 800\) MHz of spectrum. First, the FCC must identify at least 500 MHz of spectrum in the 1.3- 10.5 GHz range, excluding the aforementioned bands including (1) at least 200 MHz of federal spectrum for repurposing identified within 2 years, which must be auctioned within 4 years; and (2) identify the remaining spectrum to reach the 500 MHz goal within 4 years, which must be auctioned within 8 years. Second, the FCC is required to auction at least 300 MHz of spectrum in the upper C- band (3.98- 4.2 GHz), of which 100 MHz must be auctioned within 2 years.

The US wireless carriers are all actively working to deploy their current spectrum assets, but have acknowledged the need for additional spectrum licenses to support future needs including 6G and increased data demand. In addition to the aforementioned opportunities to acquire spectrum licenses through government auctions, the carriers will likely continue to pursue private market transactions (e.g., May 2024 proposed US Cellular sale of \(70\%\) of spectrum holdings and other assets to TMUS (\$4.4 bn), AT&T (\$1.018 bn), and Verizon (\$1.0 bn)). In our view, the FCC's spectrum auction authority will likely lead to US wireless carriers retaining more financial capacity for potential spectrum license acquisitions over the coming years.

Fixed wireless access started out as a transitional technology in response to excess spectrum capacity, but has become a core strategy that is complementary to the major wireless carriers. T- Mobile has been the most aggressive in rolling out fixed wireless access driven by its leading position in low- band and mid- band spectrum, adding an average of 1.9 mn fixed wireless subscribers each year from 2022- 2025E. Verizon and AT&T have been notably less aggressive about deploying fixed wireless with an average fixed wireless access subscriber net addition cadence over that same time period of 1.3 mn (VZ) and \(\sim 400k\) (T), respectively. Notably, Verizon's fixed wireless access net additions slowed to \(+278k\) in 2Q25A (the slowest net addition pace in FWA since 2022) due to increased competition from other fixed wireless access competitors, as well as fiber overbuilding (AT&T fiber in U- Verse markets). Although AT&T's fixed wireless access net additions in 2Q25A were \(+203k\) , a record, its growing AT&T Internet Air fixed wireless access product is benefiting from migrations from copper, which is actively being decommissioned, and will strategically serve as a top- of- funnel and stop gap in markets where AT&T will eventually have a fiber presence.

US industry wireless subscribers to continue to grow, albeit at a slowing pace; pricing to benefit from consolidation and largely rational competition. The US wireless industry, added an average of 9 million postpaid phone subscribers each year from 2021- 24, based on a bottom- up of publicly traded companies. We expect continued - albeit slowing - growth in 2025E (+8.6 million) and beyond, reflecting relatively full smartphone penetration. Industry competition has been more benign since the merger of T- Mobile and Sprint in April 2020. Although further industry consolidation (e.g., prepaid, acquisition of US Cellular by TMUS) should support rational competitive behavior, we believe that competition is increasing from benign levels - as a result of heightened promotional intensity from cable MVNOs such as Charter's Spectrum Mobile and Comcast's Xfinity Mobile, with the latter just starting to offer free lines for 1 year to its broadband subscribers.

We forecast industry postpaid phone ARPU growth at a \(1\%\) 5- year CAGR driven by continued mix shift toward new higher priced plans, price increases on existing plans ("back book"), and growing attach of add- ons. We're constructive on the growing use of bundles - whether that's wireline broadband (discussed later) or third- party services (Verizon's "Perks") - which is emerging as a growing revenue and profit pool for wireless carriers and an effective way for US Media companies to drive subscribers, while reducing churn and customer acquisition costs.

Industry wireless postpaid phone net additions to continue, but likely to decelerate in 2025E and beyond. The US wireless industry is moving toward a period of slowing growth and increasing competition, following a period of outsized growth and lower levels of competitive intensity as a result of strong consumer spending driven by low interest rates as well as the T- Mobile and Sprint merger (closed April 1, 2020). From 2021- 2024, the industry (T/VZ/TMUS/CHTR/CMCSA/ATUS) added \(\sim 37\) million postpaid wireless subscribers, at an average rate of 9.2 million per year, well ahead of 5.6 million average net addition rate realized in the preceding 4- year period form 2017- 2020. We expect postpaid phone subscriber net additions to slow to 8.6 million in 2025E, at the high- end of Verizon's industry outlook of 8.0- 8.5 million, with a continued deceleration beyond 2025E.

US smartphones approaching full penetration (we think). There were 313 million US smartphone subscribers in 2024 (postpaid and prepaid combined), representing \(92\%\) penetration (on a base of 342 mn Americans), recognizing that mobile penetration rates calculated in this way is a misnomer, since individuals can have multiple phones (Exhibit 27). In fact, a simple bottom- up tally of publicly reported wireless companies show that there were 334 million US phone subscribers (nearly \(100\%\) penetration), which includes 70 mn prepaid subscribers and 264 mn postpaid subscribers - including both smartphones and feature phones (Exhibit 28). Although we expect mobile phone penetration to increase beyond \(100\%\) given the growing usage of second- and multiple- lines, we expect the marginal industry phone net addition to become harder to come by.

We believe second-line demand is benefiting from (1) US wireless carrier marketing of second-line as a dedicated line for work, a landline replacement, close friends and family, spam management, and dating; and (2) promotional activity including free unlimited lines offered by the cable Mobile Virtual Network Operators ("MVNO") (e.g., Charter and Comcast are both offering free mobile lines for 1-year as of June 2025) as well as the major US wireless carriers (e.g., Verizon offering a free line for 1-year to existing customers that BYOD - "bring your own device" - as of June 2025).

Cable MVNO wireless products to take share of industry net- additions. We expect postpaid phone subscriber net additions to slow to 8.6 million in 2025E, at the high- end of Verizon's industry outlook of 8.0- 8.5 million, with a continued deceleration beyond 2025E (Exhibit 32). Notably, the cable MVNO's made up nearly 3.5 million postpaid wireless net additions in 2024, representing \(39\%\) of industry net additions. Going forward, we expect cable MVNO to steadily to take share, making up \(\sim 45\%\) of industry net additions from 2025- 2029E (Exhibit 33). For instance, Charter's Spectrum Mobile net additions increased to an average of \(+636k\) per quarter (4Q22- 3Q23), a meaningful step- up from the average \(+373k\) quarterly pace in the preceding 4 quarters, after launching Spectrum One in October 2022, which was a \(50 / \text{month}\) package that included 300 mbps home internet and a free unlimited wireless phone line for 1- year (Exhibit 34). More recently in March 2025, Comcast launched a similar package offering a plan priced at \(40 / \text{month}\) ( \(55 / \text{month including a 5- year price lock}\) ), which we expect will drive an acceleration in Comcast wireless net additions in 2H25 and beyond (Exhibit 35).

Mix shift toward higher plans: US wireless carriers should continue to benefit from the mix shift toward newer, higher priced, and more premium plans. In an effort to drive consumers toward newer and higher priced plans or raise pricing in general, the wireless carriers will commonly (1) have direct price increases on legacy plans (e.g., Verizon raised prices on its legacy S/M/L/XL/XXL plans in February 2025, T-Mobile raised prices on select legacy plans in April 2025); (2) reduce discounts offered for autopay or multiple lines (e.g., Verizon reduced the autopay discount by \(5 to\) 10 per month to encourage a migration to its new "myPlan"); (3) increase fees (e.g., T-Mobile increased fees charged for the costs to comply with regulatory programs by \(0.20 - 0.50 per month per line, T-Mobile's new "Experience" plans in April 2025 no longer are marketed exclusive of taxes and fees - bringing it in- line with other carriers); and (4) offer promotions, discounts, or phone trade- in credits that require the adoption of a newer (more expensive) plans.

Convergence, which is the offering of wireline and wireless as a bundled product, is in focus with cable and telecom companies both operating with the thesis that this bundle will become the preferred form of consumption. The ability to have a converged offering is constrained by broadband wireline passings with cable companies, AT&T, Verizon, and T- Mobile best positioned (in that order). Customers typically see convergence benefits through lower prices, while providers benefit from higher lifetime values and lower churn. First, in the US, a key benefit of convergence is combining a lower churn service (e.g., wireless phone service) with a higher churn service (wireline broadband) can help to reduce churn for both products. Second, although bundling multiple services together should improve lifetime value and reduce churn, we believe that bundling can be achieved in many ways - not just through combining wireless and broadband wireline. For instance, this can be achieved through multiple phone lines (i.e., family plans) or through additional services (e.g., Verizon Perks, wireless access for tablets & watches). Third, bundling typically drives discounts. For instance, Verizon offers an up to \(15 / month discount for customers with both a mobile and home internet plan. Further, many of the carriers have historically offered "4th line free" pricing plans, with additional lines after 3 lines typically only coming with a marginal fee.

That said, convergence benefits can still be offset by secular trends. For instance, cable companies, which have the largest converged footprints, have still been losing broadband subscribers despite offering wireless. We assume the cable companies would have lost more customers if not for bundling efforts.

The major telecom/cable companies have espoused differing views on convergence with most noting that bundling wireless + broadband increases the lifetime value of the customer. The companies state that bundled customers, or where the company has both fiber and wireless, churn at lower rates. T- Mobile, however, states that it sees lower churn in areas where its competitors also have fiber, implying that customers in fiber areas may have structurally lower churn (more affluent consumers churn less frequently?) than other consumers. The cable companies have put emphasis on cross- selling its broadband customers with its own wireless product (an MVNO through Verizon) while the telcos have put emphasis on their broadband products, either FWA or fiber.

AT&T, with its \(\sim 60mm\) fiber passing target by 2030, emphasizes fiber over FWA while Verizon, targeting 35- 40 mn fiber passings, has a dual- approach as FWA has been a major driver of its service revenue growth. Verizon is also in the early stages of its MDU (multi- dwelling unit) FWA product which could be an incremental driver of subscribers over time. T- Mobile's current plan calls for the fewest fiber passings (12- 15 mn by 2030) of the group. Charter has \(\sim 58mm\) passings and \(\sim 70mm\) pro forma for the proposed Cox merger while Comcast has \(\sim 64mm\) passings.
Over the past few years as the telecom companies began offering fixed wireless service

and as fiber passings became more abundant, their broadband trends have improved considerably and become a major reason for the cable companies losing customers. For broadband, we expect residential industry subscriber growth of 1.7 mn net additions in 2024 to 4.1 mn in 2029. On the wireless side, we expect industry subscriber growth to slow from 9 mn net additions in 2024 to 7 mn in 2029.

Comcast began offering wireless service in 2017 and the company has added 8.5 mn total wireless subscribers while its total broadband subscriber base has grown by 6.2 mn. From the end of 2022 when the company started to lose broadband customers, the company has added 3.2 mn wireless subscribers while losing \(\sim 780k\) broadband subscribers.

We estimate T- Mobile and AT&T will add the most net new subscribers for broadband + wireless vs. their peers. We believe AT&T's subscriber growth will actually accelerate as the company deploys incremental fiber and as its legacy broadband business becomes less of a drag.

We estimate Charter has the most converged customers within Cable as it has been the most aggressive, especially with the advent of its Spectrum One offer where subscribers receive a free year of mobile service. Comcast has recently followed with its own relatively more aggressive promotional stance to drive higher convergence. AT&T provides a converged customer metric which is defined as "AT&T Fiber subscribers that are also primary Mobility account holders that subscribe to consumer postpaid phone service."

In the exhibit below we show 'convergence' revenue growth rates. We define convergence revenue as the sum of wireless service revenue and broadband revenue. Our specific convergence revenue estimates by company include:

- AT&T 
- Our convergence revenue estimate is the sum of Consumer postpaid phone service revenue (estimate), Prepaid revenue, and Broadband revenue. Our pro forma estimate includes only our current Lumen fiber broadband revenue estimate and no benefit of stronger go-to market initiatives.- Altice 
- Our convergence revenue estimate is the sum of Mobile service revenue and Residential broadband revenue.- Charter 
- Our convergence revenue estimate is the sum of Residential wireless revenue and Residential broadband revenue.- Comcast 
- Our convergence revenue estimate is the sum of Domestic residential wireless revenue and Domestic residential broadband revenue.- T-Mobile 
- Our convergence revenue estimate is the sum of Postpaid phone service revenue, Prepaid revenue, FWA revenue (estimated as not disclosed), and Fiber revenue (estimated as not disclosed).- Verizon 
- Our convergence revenue estimate is the sum of Consumer postpaid phone service revenue (estimated), Consumer prepaid revenue (estimated), Consumer FWA revenue (estimated), and Consumer Fiber revenue (estimated). Our pro forma estimate includes only our current Frontier fiber broadband revenue estimate and no benefit of stronger go-to market initiatives.

While this does not represent 'converged' revenue per se given we do not know how many telecom broadband subscribers also purchase wireless, we view this as a barometer of the trends in the business. On this basis, T-Mobile has the fastest CAGR at \(\sim 6.0\%\) (helped by US Cellular and fiber M&A) with AT&T second at \(4.3\%\) . Altice and Verizon are the slowest growers, through Verizon's gap to Comcast/Charter narrows when flowing through Frontier's broadband revenue trends. AT&T's CAGR increases to \(4.5\%\) when including Lumen's fiber revenue from \(4.3\%\) on a standalone basis. AT&T and Verizon could drive even faster growth than the simple addition of their proposed acquisitions given we expect both to emphasize converged bundles.

Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Our prevailing view is that bundling should reduce subscriber acquisition cost (SAC) which should help improve margins over time. Cable can only offer their wireless product to their broadband customers, giving the company clear insight for which subscribers to target to upsell. We also believe wireless is a strong way for the cable companies to 'save' broadband churners given the cost benefit. This does not appear to be having a real impact on the business today, however, as two opposite forces are impacting cable's margins: (1) Broadband competition is more fierce than years ago, driving customer declines and fewer pricing opportunities and (2) Wireless is an expensive industry and MVNO's historically do not have strong margins.

In the exhibits below, we show Comcast's Cable segment (historic reporting) adj. EBITDA margin and adj. EBITDA less video gross margin expansion over time. We look at adj. EBITDA less video gross margin as video gross margins are clearly distinct from the remainder of the business. From 2016- 2022, adj. EBITDA margins expanded by 480bps or \(\sim 80\) bps per year on average while adj. EBITDA less video gross margins expanded by almost 1,600bps or 260bps per year on average. Comcast was able to

show strong ARPU growth over this time while driving material subscriber growth. Looking to the new disclosures (and our forecasts), we forecast from 2023- 2029 the company will expand its Connectivity and Platforms adj. EBITDA margins by \(\sim 140bps\) , or \(\sim 20bps\) per year on average. Similarly, we see adj. EBITDA less video gross margins expanding by 210bps. Part of the reason we see little margin expansion is that we forecast Comcast's marketing expense to grow \(6\%\) in 2025 and \(5\%\) in 2026 as it focuses on growing its wireless business.
Exhibit 47: Comcast reported strong margin expansion historically while broadband subscribers continued to trend higher Comcast's historic Cable segment margin expansion (vs. 2016)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 48: We forecast minimal margin expansion for Comcast as broadband trends remain a headwind while costs are increasing to drive wireless subscribers Comcast C&P EBITDA margin expansion (vs. 2023)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

From 2016- 2022, Charter expanded its adj. EBITDA margins by 390bps while adj. EBITDA less video gross margins expanded by over 1,000bps. We see similar margin expansion for Charter and Comcast over the next few years as both companies are focused on cost controls though Charter has already anniversaried its Spectrum One wireless offer and has stronger broadband subscriber trends (though we expect it to remain negative), and is attempting to improve its video business with the inclusion of DTC applications. What concerns us on further margin expansion is the lack of subscriber growth. While we believe both Charter and Comcast are focused on subscriber growth, it appears to us it is more of a focus for Charter. As such, if competitive dynamics continue or worsen, on the broadband side, the companies could spend incremental capital on marketing/advertising/promotion in an attempt to drive improved subscriber trends.
Exhibit 49: We expect Charter to drive some margin expansion but a lack of subscriber growth could pressure further improvements Charter margin expansion (vs. 2016)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Pay TV trends, inclusive of stronger Direct- to- Consumer bundles, could improve broadband subscriber growth. Broadband expectations for \(2025+\) for Charter and Comcast have diverged, and we think a major reason investors expect this difference is partially due to Charter's emphasis on new video packages, encompassing many DTC offerings. Charter's packages and value are not available at other providers and if consumers demand this package of traditional linear video with DTC offerings, it could be a differentiator for Charter to improve its broadband net addition trends. Charter has begun to report significantly improved video net additions, losing only 80k subscribers in 2Q25k vs. 408k in 2Q24 while Comcast's 2Q25 losses were 325k vs. 419k in 2Q24. We believe investors want to see proof that new video packages are actually improving broadband trends before underwriting material improvements.

Charter and Comcast have had similar broadband net addition trends dating back to at least 2016 but 1Q25 results and 2025 expectations have begun to diverge. The major debate point between these two stocks is how this divergence can be so large for two companies that have similar footprint sizes and similar product offerings. While it is too early to know if Charter's renewed emphasis on its video product offering, inclusive of bundled DTC products, will drive improved broadband subscriber performance, we believe it could prove incrementally beneficial vs. the cable wireless offerings.

For 2025 through 2029, the Street (per Visible Alpha) is modeling more than 800k total broadband losses at Charter but more than 2,000k losses at Comcast. From 4Q19 (first quarter before COVID) through 4Q25, we estimate Charter will cumulatively add \(\sim 625k\) more broadband net additions than Comcast. Charter has invested incrementally into its rural footprint which has added \(\sim 350k\) broadband subscribers since the beginning of 2023 - adjusting broadband net additions for these rural subscribers, we estimate Charter will outperform Comcast by \(\sim 275k\) . Charter has \(\sim 6.8m\) fewer total passings than Comcast but its penetration has been slightly stronger.

We believe cable bulls think wireless will ultimately improve the profitability and cash flows of the cable companies over time. Given the negative broadband trends the companies have reported, we (and cable bears) have not seen any evidence that

wireless is helping to drive broadband subscriber growth. The companies note that broadband churn remains at or near record lows, implying mobile is helping broadband churn but it doesn't appear wireless is driving better broadband gross additions. Both Charter and Comcast have invested into their wireless businesses to 1) drive incremental profitability per subscriber, 2) reduce broadband churn, and 3) improve lifetime value per subscriber. Charter has been more front-footed with its wireless ambitions though Comcast has discussed becoming more aggressive in 2025 - and this results in Charter's \(\sim 1,000\) bps greater penetration of wireless as a percent of its broadband subscriber base at \(36\%\) vs. \(27\%\) . The company's penetration rates started to diverge at the end of 2022 in tandem with Charter's Spectrum One offer where customers could purchase broadband and receive a free mobile line.

Tax changes in the One Big Beautiful Bill are a material positive for free cash flow generation for the telecom and cable companies. First, most companies will be able to reinvest a portion of the tax savings into further building out their infrastructure. AT&T is being the most aggressive in using proceeds to invest and it will accelerate its fiber passing target by an incremental 1 mn passings per year for a total of 4 mn. This should drive accelerated fiber revenue and EBITDA growth. Second, stronger free cash flow conversion should be positive across the board for leverage metrics as well. In our view, better- than- expected cash taxes and free cash flow conversion could help accelerate already generous upcoming shareholder capital returns including accelerating buybacks from AT&T and T- Mobile over the next several years, and the start of share repurchases from Verizon.

The One Big Beautiful Bill provides for permanent full expensing of equipment which should drive improved cash flow conversion across the sector. We believe the law creates real cash flow benefits to the group and each of the companies have outlined their preliminary savings and reinvestment strategies.

AT&T expects to realize \(6.5 - 8.0bn\) of total savings from 2025- 2027 vs. prior guidance. It plans on investing \(3.5bn\) of these savings for accelerated fiber deployments, increasing its passings targets by 1mn annually, resulting in 4 mn homes passed per year beginning in 2026. This will drive AT&T's fiber passings (per management expectations) to \(\sim 60\) mn inclusive of JVs and its planned Lumen fiber acquisition by the end of the decade. Lastly, AT&T will contribute \(1.5bn\) of tax savings to fund its employee pension plan. While cash conversion from EBITDA will improve with new tax laws, the company continues to plan to operate within prior leverage targets.

Verizon raised its 2025 free cash flow guidance by \(\) 2\(bn at 2Q25 results, and we estimate\) \ \(1.75\) bn of the raise was from tax reform adjustments. The company did not change its capital allocation priorities or CapEx budget. The company will have \(80 - 90\%\) of its mid- band C- band spectrum deployed by the end of 2025 and should be completed by the end of 2026. With its wireless network in a good position before a potential spectrum auction later in the decade, Verizon could use some of its tax savings to invest in faster fiber builds once the Frontier acquisition closes. During the 2Q25 earnings call, management noted that as it nears the closing of the Frontier acquisition, it will provide an updated strategy, broadband expansion, and capital allocation update and that is when we believe the company could increase its current fiber passing expectations.

T- Mobile notes that the One Big Beautiful Bill will have limited impact on 2025 cash taxes but will reduce 2026 cash taxes by \(\sim\) 1.5 bn vs. prior expectations. The company is less prescriptive on its planned use of capital other than it plans to continue its current capital allocation philosophy.
Charter now expects to pay \(\sim\) 1 bn in cash taxes in 2025, down from \(\) 1.6- 2.0\(bn

previously. Management expects the new law will save the company several billion dollars over the next five years. Specifically, Charter believes the law can drive \(\sim \$ 10\) of FCF/sh uplift. With a better cash conversion, the company also notes that more projects could meet its ROI hurdles, potentially giving the company more capacity to further build out its footprint.

Comcast estimates the bill will drive a \(\sim \$ 1\) bn annual savings for the next several years. We believe Comcast could reinvest \(\sim 50\%\) of the savings back into its network infrastructure.
Lumen expects to receive a cash tax refund in the range of \(\$ 300 - \$ 400\) mn in 2025 vs. its prior expectation of a \(\$ 100 - \$ 200\) mn payment.

Upcoming iPhone device innovation should drive greater device demand across both existing and new members of the US iPhone installed base, which should increase the customer switching pool driven by increased demand for device upgrades and likely heightened device- related promotions. We estimate AAPL's iPhone revenue should grow \(+5\% / + 7\%\) in F2025/F2026 (Exhibit 59), supported by upcoming product releases (Exhibit 61). Specifically, we expect reported upcoming form factor changes over the next several years to support iPhone device demand, including the "thinner" iPhone 17 Air model (September 2025), a foldable iPhone 18 model (September 2026), and all- glass display on the iPhone 19 (September 2027). Accordingly, we forecast iPhone shipments to grow annually through F2028 as the annual device replacement cycle, which we estimate has grown to nearly 5.6 years as of F2025E (v. \(\sim 3.8\) years F2017), begins to shorten through F2028E (4.6 years, GSe). We observe that in recent years, US carriers have offered substantial levels of device subsidies associated with switching providers or updating one's plan (Exhibit 68), which we believe has contributed to growing US user preference for premium devices over time (Exhibit 67). As such, we believe that growing demand for iPhones, across both new and existing users, supported by innovation across Apple's upcoming generations of product releases, should drive carrier market share shifts towards providers offering attractive device- related promotions.

We assume coverage of AT&T (T) with a Buy rating and a 12- month target price of \(\) 32\(. AT&T is the largest provider of consumer and commercial fiber broadband services and is the third - largest US mobile network operator. We believe the company's fiber initiative can drive sustained Consumer Wireline segment EBITDA growth while its Wireless business should continue its positive trends, and coupled with cost controls, should continue to drive EBITDA and ultimately free cash flow growth through at least 2029. Our view is summarized by the following key points.

Fiber deployments should drive accelerating net additions, propelling Consumer Wireline service revenue and EBITDA growth. AT&T is targeting 60 mn homes passed with fiber by 2030, and we believe this will result in double- digit broadband revenue growth. As the company's legacy broadband business becomes a smaller portion of the overall segment, total broadband revenue growth should accelerate in the later part of the decade. We believe upside in this segment vs. our current (and Street) estimates could occur through a higher fiber penetration rate and faster ARPU growth. Overall, we see fiber deployments driving a \(\sim 13\%\) EBITDA CAGR (2024E- 2029E) in the Consumer Wireline with potential upside from higher fiber penetration rate and faster ARPU growth.

We expect steady Wireless ARPU growth and net additions but churn remains a risk. For the past few years, AT&T focused on improving its customer churn metrics through offering its base the same deals as new customers. Churn declined materially and the company was able to raise prices and drive solid wireless EBITDA growth. We expect the company will be able to steadily increase ARPU from here through a mix of price increases and customers self- selecting up the rate curve. We believe the company should be able to generate \(1mn+\) phone net additions for the next few years, driving \(2 - 3\%\) service revenue and \(3 - 4\%\) EBITDA growth. Churn industrywide has been increasing - likely due to the amount of price increases in the market - and while we remain positive on AT&T's ability to drive solid profitability growth in the segment, we are watching to see how industry churn dynamics evolve.

Capital allocation changes are driving - double- digit FCF/sh growth. After approaching its leverage target, AT&T shifted its capital allocation policy earlier this year to begin repurchasing shares. The company is targeting \(\) 4bn\(of repurchases in 2025 and aims to accelerate the pace of share repurchases under its\) \ \(40\) bn, 3- year shareholder capital return program ( \(\) 20\(bn dividends,\) \ \(20\) bn buybacks). We model accelerating share repurchases with \(\) 6/\(\) 10\(bn in 2026E/2027E. Said differently, AT&T will likely repurchase a cumulative\) \ \(16\) bn of T stock in 2026E- 2027E, or \(\sim 8\%\) of its current market capitalization. Core profitability growth and buybacks drive our 2026- 2028 FCF/sh growth of \(14\%\) on average, implying a \(10\times 2027\) FCF/sh multiple, which we view as attractive. We believe the total cash returns (buybacks plus
dividend) of \(\sim 35\%\) from 2025E- 29E as potentially accretive to the multiple over time.

- Our 12-month target price of \(32\) reflects \(7.0X\) NTM+1Y EV/EBITDA. Our target EV/EBITDA multiple is toward the high end of T's historical range given faster than historical sustainable profitability and FCF growth and incrementally positive capital allocation dynamics.

AT&T's fiber expansion strategy should accelerate segment growth on 60M fiber passings target. AT&T has guided to mid- to- high teens fiber broadband growth for 2025 and mid- teens annually through 2027. The company reported \(18\%\) fiber revenue growth in 2024 with fiber connections growing \(12\%\) and ARPU growing \(4\%\) . Subscriber growth was negatively impacted by a union strike in 3Q24 where the company stopped marketing its service in the southeast for \(\sim 30\) days. AT&T's overall broadband revenue grew \(7\%\) in 2024 as legacy declines partly offset growth in fiber. As legacy broadband subscribers become a smaller portion of AT&T's broadband base, we believe broadband revenue growth should be able to sustain or accelerate over time. The company is guiding to low- to- mid teens EBITDA growth in 2025, with a double- digit CAGR through 2027. This multi- year growth rate should drive Consumer Wireline margins to \(\sim 40\%\) which is in line with cable peers Comcast and Charter. We estimate that AT&T's fiber revenue will grow at a \(15\%\) three year CAGR from 2024- 27. Specifically, we estimate that total Broadband revenue will account for \(\sim 90\%\) of segment revenue by the end of the decade from \(65\%\) in 2019 and that Fiber revenue will increase from \(\)4\(bn in 2021 to\) \sim \$15bn in 2029.
Exhibit 72: We expect Fiber revenue to increase from \(\sim 30\%\) of Consumer Wireline revenue in 2021 to \(\sim 70\%\) in 2029 AT&T Consumer Wireline revenue by type (\$, mn)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We currently model 47 mn fiber passings at the end of 2029 and 41 mn fiber served locations vs. 45 mn (50 mn inclusive of JVs) 2029 fiber passings target, equivalent to \(\sim 4\) mn per year. We estimate these builds will drive \(>1\) mn fiber net additions each year through at least 2029 and we sit \(2\%\) above consensus on 2029E fiber subscribers. We forecast AT&T will drive fiber penetration (vs. its Fiber Served Locations metric) of \(38\%\) in 2029 vs. \(40\%\) at 4Q24, and we view this as relatively conservative and expect in the
medium- to- long- term this will accrete closer to \(50\%\) as fiber builds mature.

We expect steady ARPU growth and net additions but churn remains a risk. AT&T has improved its go- to market strategy over the past few years and has been able to consistently grow its postpaid phone subscriber base through a major focus on churn reduction. That said, given the preponderance of price increases in the market, churn for the wireless carriers has started to increase. AT&T's 1Q25 churn increased by 11 bps Y/Y while 2Q25 increased by 17 bps Y/Y - this compares to Verizon at \(+6\) bps Y/Y in 1Q25 and \(+12\) bps in 2Q and T- Mobile at \(+5\) bps Y/Y in 1Q25 and \(+10\) bps in 2Q. We believe AT&T can sustain solid wireless service revenue growth, and we are modeling postpaid service revenue growth of \(\sim 3\%\) in 2025- 2028 driven by \(1\%\) annual ARPU growth and \(2\%\) subscriber growth.

Solid fundamentals coupled with expense controls and a new buyback authorization should drive double digit FCF/sh growth. We believe AT&T has proven over the last few years that it is capable of executing its go- to- market plan and driving sustainable profitability growth. The company is currently incurring \$6 bn of annual legacy operating expense, with \(60\%\) in geographic focused costs (power, maintenance, real estate) and \(40\%\) in direct customer costs (installation and customer care). In "Wireless First" areas (where AT&T has no plan to build residential fiber, which constitutes \(10\%\) of the population but \(50\%\) of the land area), the company is planning to exit legacy services by 2027 by offering wireless and satellite alternatives. In "Fiber First" areas (where the company is rolling out fiber), AT&T expects to exit legacy services by 2029. With LSD/MSD EBITDA growth and stable capital investment, we see AT&T generating HSD/LDD free cash flow growth and a \(\sim 3\%\) buyback should drive \(\sim \mathsf{DD}\) free cash flow per share growth through at least 2029.

We assume coverage of T- Mobile (TMUS) with a Buy rating and a 12- month target price of \(286. T- Mobile is the second- largest mobile network operator in the US and a relatively new entrant in broadband with its fixed wireless access product ("5G Home Internet") and wireline broadband through various joint ventures (e.g., Metronet, Lumos). TMUS should realize an industry- leading \(7\%\) EBITDA 5- year CAGR reflecting the company's market leadership in mobile and emerging growth in fiber. First, T- Mobile should continue to gain the lion's share of postpaid phone net additions for the next few years. We model 2.4 mn average annual postpaid phone net additions from 2025E- 2029E as TMUS should have continued success with its relatively attractive pricing and consumer promotions (e.g., T- Mobile Tuesdays, free select streaming services). The US Cellular wireless operations acquisition (closed August 1, 2025 for \(4.3bn\) should drive upside to TMUS consensus EBITDA in 3Q25E and 2025E, with further potential upside to its \(1.0bn\) of cost and capex synergies. Second, T- Mobile is expanding its ambitions in broadband with a goal to pass 12- 15 mn homes with fiber by 2030E (6.5 mn from Metronet v. 2 mn in 2024 and 3.5 mn from Lumos by 2028E v. \(\sim 475k\) in 1Q25) and reach 12 mn fixed wireless access subscribers by 2028E (v. prior target of 7.5 mn by 2025E). TMUS' growing fiber passings and fixed wireless access availability should drive broadband revenue while driving synergies with wireless through a converged offering. Third, TMUS trades at a premium to peers at 10x EV/EBITDA and 15x P/FCF. We see TMUS' relative valuation as justified reflecting TMUS' faster EBITDA growth (e.g., \(7\%\) 5- year CAGR 2024- 2029E v. \(3\%\) average of peers) and market leading service revenue to FCF conversion (26% of Service revenue in 2024 v. peers of \(17\%\) ). However, we think this positive outlook is already partly reflected in the stock's premium multiple relative to peers. Our view is summarized by the following key points.

The wireless business will continue to grow faster than peers. We see T- Mobile continuing to take share in the market, but likely at a moderating pace given 1) the size of its business, 2) incremental competition from Verizon, and 3) incremental competition from cable, especially Comcast. While we expect the company to continue to grab the largest \(1\%\) of net subscriber growth, we think this is in line with expectations. While T- Mobile's pricing is generally at a discount to its peers, there are concerns in the market that the carriers have taken too much price (see higher churn for all three telcos) and could limit incremental pricing actions if T- Mobile wants to stay under its peers pricing umbrella. We find T- Mobile's relative value/network quality combination as attractive in the market and gives us confidence in its best- in- class subscriber growth.

Fiber investments create a new growth avenue for broadband but scale ambitions remains unknown. T- Mobile has been experimenting with fiber broadband deployments through partnerships and JVs and announced the largest of

its deals, Metronet, last year. The company has been deploying fiber in a capital light model, using partners to help fund the build while it uses its marketing muscle and customer experience expertise to drive subscriber growth. Given its capital- light strategy, however, the company will retain capital for shareholder returns which we view as vital to the stock. We see uncertainty on what T- Mobile's long- term fiber ambitions are and how much of its own capital it is willing to invest as the company downplays convergence benefits but simultaneously is investing in fiber.

Valuation premium vs. peers is likely to remain but see limits to further multiple expansion in the near- term. We see TMUS trading at 10x EV/EBITDA vs. T at 7x and VZ at 6x. T- Mobile is growing its EBITDA at a premium rate (7% 2024- 29 5 year CAGR vs. AT&T at 4% and Verizon at 3%) though we think investors already are reflecting upside to the company's multiyear targets in addition to upside to synergy realization for the US Cellular acquisition.

Our 12- month target price of \(286\) reflects 10.5X NTM+1Y EV/EBITDA. Our target EV/EBITDA multiple is near the high end of TMUS's historical range given industry competition factors, growth, and capital allocation dynamics as outlined above.

T- Mobile continues to drive best in- class wireless growth, but we expect some moderation over time. We see T- Mobile continuing to be the postpaid phone net add leader and to drive service revenue and EBITDA growth above peers. In fact, we see T- Mobile driving \(\sim 2x\) faster service revenue growth compared to AT&T and Verizon. This is being generated through \(\sim 150 - 200\) bps faster subscriber growth vs. AT&T and \(\sim 300 - 350\) bps faster vs. Verizon. T- Mobile's growth rate should converge closer to its peers over time as subscriber growth and pricing growth slow.

- T-Mobile could encounter more intense competition from its consumer wireless competitors, which could drive worse-than-expected revenue and margins;- Fixed wireless access could see heightened competition from broadband peers in the cable and fiber industries;- Spectrum availability and the lack of US spectrum auctions could create network congestion and negatively impact subscriber trends;- T-Mobile could choose to deploy significantly more capital for fiber broadband.

We assume coverage of Verizon Communications (VZ) with a Buy rating and a 12- month target price of \(49. Verizon is the largest mobile network operator in the US, as well as a significant provider of consumer and commercial broadband access services. We're encouraged by Verizon's efforts to drive growth through continued wireless service ARPU growth through Perks, promotional amortization roll- offs, and pricing, while also benefiting from MVNO service revenue - primarily through its agreements with Comcast and Charter. In addition, we expect Verizon's growth in fiber passings from about 19 mn in 2025E to 32 mn in 2029E (v. target of 30 mn by 2028E and 35- 40 mn over time, pro- forma for the proposed acquisition of Frontier) should help drive an acceleration in Fios internet subscriber net additions. That said, we expect Verizon's post- paid phone subscriber net additions to be the slowest among the national wireless carriers over the next several years reflecting Verizon's position as the wireless market leader while facing competition from T- Mobile (lower price, network leadership), AT&T (convergence leader), and to- a- lesser extent cable (lower priced). Within Business, Verizon may see increased competition from cable following their new MVNO agreement with T- Mobile. Our Buy rating reflects what we view as heightened uncertainty and execution risks related to: 1) consumer postpaid phone net additions given increased industry competition and Verizon's relative premium pricing; 2) recent elevated levels consumer postpaid phone churn; and 3) the convergence strategy and integration risks related to the proposed Frontier acquisition but more than offset by potential upside from Frontier (if completed), Perks revenue and profitability, and capital allocation upside. Our view is summarized by the following key points.

Wireless subscriber net additions likely to lag competitors, but ARPU tailwinds and investments in brand perception (e.g., Perks, Best Value Guarantee, myAccess/myPlan) likely to improve trends over time. With 93 mn postpaid phone subscribers, Verizon is the largest mobile network operator in the US. Although we forecast continued postpaid phone subscriber net additions (+470k on average from 2025E- 2029E), Verizon likely will exhibit the slowest growth among the big three national wireless carrier reflecting T- Mobile lower prices and AT&T's leadership in convergence. We laud Verizon's efforts for continuing to invest to improve its price- value perception through efforts including (1) Best Value Guarantee (e.g., 3- year price lock, free phone with trade- in); (2) myAccess (e.g., rewards, deals, events/experiences); and (3) Perks (e.g., discounts on add- on services). Despite new plans with price locks, we believe that the removal of discounts, continued migration to higher priced plans, growing adoption of Perks (\$2 bn run- rate revenue at mid 30% margins), and waning promotional amortization headwinds should drive sustained ARPU growth in 2026E.

Broadband segment could be bolstered by fixed wireless and proposed Frontier acquisition. With 18- 19 million fiber passings today, Verizon is the second largest US fiber provider (AT&T has \(\sim 30\) mn fiber passings). With converged

offerings becoming more prevalent among cable competitors (e.g., Comcast and Charter have 64/57 mn passings) and AT&T, we believe that Verizon is currently at a disadvantage outside of Fios fiber markets. That said, Verizon's broadband investments through organic fiber builds, fixed wireless deployments, and the proposed Frontier acquisition (early 2026 target closing), should eventually drive \(\sim 1.5\mathrm{mn}\) (GSe) annual broadband (fiber + fixed wireless) additions through 2029. The company notes that \(45\%\) of its fiber base also has a mobility product while \(75 - 80\%\) of FWA subs take mobility, implying \(16\%\) of its postpaid wireless base is a converged customer. Verizon expects this to double over the next three years which should help reduce churn and drive improved subscriber acquisition. Given Verizon's 35- 40mn fiber passings target over time (inclusive of Frontier), we see the company well positioned in convergence relative to T- Mobile's asset mix but behind AT&T and its 60mn fiber passing target by 2030.

Proposed Frontier acquisition could create synergy upside optionality. We see potential improvement in the business in conjunction with the proposed Frontier acquisition (not included in our estimates or price target). We believe there are four main buckets of potential upside with the Frontier deal (if completed) including 1) better than forecasted cost synergies, 2) revenue and subscriber upside, 3) debt refinancing, and 4) usage of Frontier's net operating losses (NOLs). Specifically, we believe Verizon has lower wireless share with Frontier fiber customers than its nationwide average and with bundling opportunities post- deal, we expect Verizon to lean into this convergence opportunity. Verizon has \(\sim 1,000\) stores in the Frontier footprint, and we expect Verizon to cross- sell wireless to Frontier fiber customers and fiber to Verizon wireless customers. Frontier notes its weighted average interest rate is \(6.8\%\) on its debt outstanding which is higher than Verizon's cost of capital. Lastly, Frontier carries significant NOLs which Verizon should be able to utilize. We see a hard upcoming catalyst on this topic later in the year/early next year when we expect Verizon to give a further update on the deal including potential synergy upside and an updated capital allocation plan. We see a potential buyback catalyst in 2027, with the potential for this to occur sooner- than- expected due to cash tax savings due to corporate tax reform offset by the risk of incremental cash preservation ahead of the upcoming FCC spectrum auctions.

Our 12- month target price of \(49 is based on 6.5X NTM + 1Y EV/EBITDA multiple. Our target EV/EBITDA multiple is toward the upper half of VZ's historical range given improving growth and capital allocation dynamics as outlined above.

Consumer postpaid phone subscriber trends have been challenged, but new price- value investments could help. Verizon's consumer wireless performance has underperformed peers and has not added any net new subscribers since at least 2020 (Exhibit 89). The company has been focused on improving trends in this segment and is targeting an 80/20 price/subscriber mix to drive top line trends. Verizon added 82k consumer postpaid phone subscribers in 2024, but we estimate 67k subscriber losses in 2025 with higher- than- expected churn the main diver for worse Y/Y subscriber trends.

In our view, Verizon's postpaid phone subscriber challenges are likely in part due to its premium pricing (Exhibit 90), combined with improving network quality from T-Mobile and AT&T. As a counterpoint, Verizon appears to have acknowledged its price- value perception issues and has responded with programs like the Best Value Guarantee for new and existing customers, which provides a 3- year price lock guarantee and a free phone (earned out over 36 months) on any plan with a trade- in, as well as savings on streaming services.

Verizon (and AT&T and T- Mobile) has been raising its price on its service but it appears quite clear that this is driving higher churn. This could be a risk to future ARPU (and service revenue estimates) if the carriers are unable to raise price further. Verizon's focus on customer up- take of 'perks' is an under- the- radar benefit to service revenue and EBITDA. Management said it expects customers to take 15mn perks by the end of the year, up from \(>10mn\) at 1Q25 results, and \(\sim 7mn\) in October 2024 which equates to a \(\) 2\(bn annual run - rate business at the end of the year. Assuming customers subscribed to 8mn perks at the end of 2024, it implies an annualized\) \ \(960\) mn (at \(\) 10\(/perk) of service revenue and\) \ \(290\) mn of EBITDA (at \(30\%\) ), all else equal. If the company can execute to 15mn perks by the end of 2025, it implies \(\sim\) 1,500 mn \((+\) 900 mn Y/Y) in service revenue in 2025 and \(\sim\) 450 mn of EBITDA \((+\) 270 mn Y/Y). This implies that \(\sim\) 900 mn of service revenue growth came from perks or \(\sim 45\%\) of its \(\) 1.95\(bn service revenue growth at the midpoint of its 2.0 - 2.8\%\) guidance range. Similarly, Verizon's 2025 adj. EBITDA growth guidance calls for 2.5 - 3.5% growth \((+\) 1.5bn Y/Y at the midpoint) and perks would account for just below 20% of this growth. Less than 1/3 of myPlan customers subscribe to any Perks today, with ample runway to improve Perks penetration.

Buybacks unlikely in the very near term but could appear post- Frontier (if completed). We believe Verizon is now well positioned to deliver steady growth in revenue and EBITDA over the next few years and expect it to show improved performance should it close the Frontier acquisition (expected in 1Q26). - Verizon could encounter more intense competition from its consumer wireless competitors, which could drive worse-than-expected revenue and margins;- Fixed wireless access could see unexpected competition from higher performance broadband products including fiber and newer DOCSIS cable standards;- The company could see reduced growth expectations as a result of limited spectrum availability and the lack of US spectrum auctions;- Verizon's business wireline franchise could deteriorate more rapidly than we expect;- The proposed Frontier integration could have unexpected difficulties.

We assume coverage of ATUS with a Sell rating and a 12- month target price of \(\) 2.00\(for\) 15\%\(downside vs. - 1\%\) upside for the rest of our coverage. Altice is a regional broadband operator which provides a range of broadband, video, and mobile connectivity services. We see the broadband landscape continuing to be competitive with cable being pinched from FWA on the low end and fiber on the high end. We forecast \(0\%\) EBITDA growth over the next 5 years (2024- 29E CAGR), which limits underlying FCF growth and the ATUS' ability to deliver. With ATUS at 7.8X net leverage (company defined, last 2- quarter EBITDA annualized) and cable peers - CMCSA and CHTR - trading \(
long- term revenue upside.

High leverage, negative subscriber trends, and limited FCF drive an uncertain outlook. Altice currently stands at \(\sim 7.8x\) net leverage (company defined), EBITDA is set to be flat for the next five years, broadband subscribers are likely to decline for the next few years, and cumulative FCF from 2025 through 2029 accounts for only \(7\%\) of current net debt. All together, the stock trades at a premium to peers, has similar or worse subscriber trends, and worse EBITDA/FCF trends. Without a clear catalyst on the horizon, we see limited upside potential in the stock.

Altice's residential broadband penetration peaked at \(\sim 49\%\) in 2020 but has steadily fallen as a \(\%\) of homes passed to \(\sim 40\%\) today. What we find most concerning is that since 4Q19, the company has passed an incremental \(\sim 1\mathrm{mn}\) new locations but the residential subscriber base has declined from \(4.2\mathrm{mn}\) to \(3.9\mathrm{mn}\) . Altice is in the midst of overbuilding its cable network with FTTH. FTTH penetration rates have increased materially since the company began reporting the metric with 2019 penetration at \(1\%\) , increasing to \(22\%\) as of 2Q25. Altic is guiding to flat EBITDA in 2025 but sustainable growth is likely predicated on broadband subscriber trends. Altic has delivered Y/Y EBITDA declines since 2021 but is guiding to flat EBITDA in 2025. Our estimates are broadly in- line with the Street for the next few years, but this implies a 2024- 2029 CAGR of \(0\%\) . This is below our Charter/Comcast EBITDA growth estimates and both of those stocks trade at discounts to ATUS. We believe sustainable EBITDA growth will difficult until the company can show consistent subscriber growth. Given the competitive broadband dynamics outlined above, Altic's SG&A expenses, including advertising and promotion costs, could trend higher as the company looks to maintain its subscriber base - if subscriber trends do not improve, we think investors are unlikely to want to own the equity.
