Limited FCF, high leverage, and a negative subscriber outlook pressures investor optimism. Altice currently has \(\sim \$ 1\) bn in equity value relative to its net debt position of \(\$ 25\) bn on a base of \(\$ 3.4\) bn of EBITDA, implying just \(0.3x\) of equity in its valuation. A \(0.1x\) change in valuation would imply a \(\) 0.70\(change in stock price or a roughly 30\%\) move. Given the limited equity in Altice's capital structure, small changes in valuation drive major changes in the stock price. We believe this dynamic creates a valuation challenge for investors. Altice currently trades at \(\sim 7.5x\) 2026 EV/EBITDA, a premium vs. Cable peers CHTR (6X) and Comcast (5X) and the price Charter is paying for Cox (6.4X). Given the trajectory of Altice's net additions, EBITDA, and FCF, we do not believe the company warrants a premium valuation. If we apply CHTR's EV/EBITDA multiple to ATUS, it implies a negative equity value. Given the amount of free cash flow, we believe it will be difficult for the company to meaningfully deliver in the medium term. Based on our estimates, we do not have Altice's leverage falling below Charter's EV/EBITDA multiple in our forecast period through 2029E. However, a fix to Altice's capital structure would potentially create upside for FCF and also could drive increased interest in the stock.
Exhibit 105: We believe that Altice's free cash flow trends will remain relatively weak, which will make right-sizing the company's capital structure more difficult
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We currently see downside risk to Altice shares based on our view of increasing competitive intensity in the broadband business, driven by the longer- range viability of fixed wireless access and fiber offerings. We view the current capital structure as sub- optimal with leverage slightly below 8X with limited free cash flow. We could be more positive on ATUS stock under varying scenarios including if:

- The wireless carrier's network reaches a point of congestion where either 1) FWA customers start to churn faster or 2) the carriers stop offering FWA service to new customers. This would improve the competitive dynamic in the industry for Altice and could foreshadow broadband subscriber growth.- The telecom companies pull back on fiber deployment plans, which also would help the competitive dynamic in the market.- Altice is able to show sustained EBITDA growth, a material concern today, even with 2H25 guidance implying a substantial acceleration from 1H.- The company is able to deliver meaningfully to trend towards a more sustainable capital structure. We believe the company is too highly levered and with shrinking subscribers and EBITDA, there is little investor confidence the company will be able to overcome this issue.- If Altice's cable peer valuation multiples are able to expand, it would potentially provide upside to the stock. Altice is currently levered higher than where both Charter and Comcast currently trade.

Fixed wireless access and fiber net adds begin to slow, or Altice begins to deliver a better trajectory of subscriber additions; Fiber competitors could begin to slow their deployments significantly; The company could become the target of potential M&A, which could drive significant equity upside; A significant change in capital structure could be a material positive for the equity.

We assume coverage of Charter Communications (CHTR) with a Sell rating and a 12- month target price of \(\) 223\(for 15\%\) downside vs. \(- 1\%\) upside for the rest of our coverage. Charter is the second- largest cable network operator in the US (first- largest pro- forma for the announced acquisition of Cox). Competition in wireline broadband is intensifying for US cable operators like Charter reflecting a growing number of fiber passings as telecom operators pursue wireless and fiber broadband convergence, as well as increased fixed wireless access availability due to underutilized spectrum. We forecast continued broadband subscriber declines and see limited broadband pricing growth reflecting competition from a higher- quality fiber alternative and lower- priced fixed wireless access. We believe Charter will struggle to grow its subscriber base in the near term, and it may be forced to sustain an elevated level of investment to maintain its market position. CHTR announced the acquisition of Cox Communications (private), which is expected by CHTR to close in mid- 2026. The addition of Cox's \(\sim 6\) mn US broadband subscribers will make CHTR the largest US cable broadband operator ( \(\sim 36\) mn pro- forma subscribers), resulting in \(\) 500\(mn of cost synergies, with additional upside from revenue and capex synergies. That said, we see limited changes to the outlook for the competitive outlook in broadband following the deal, which is dilutive (pre- synergy) at a headline transaction multiple of\) 6.4X 2025E EV/EBITDA (v. CHTR trading at 6X). Despite our cautious view on CHTR, we acknowledge that valuation is attractive and undemanding with CHTR stock trading at a 14% free cash flow yield (2026E) or 29% free cash flow yield (2028E) when the company expects to capex to decline to \(\sim\) 8 bn (2028E) from \(\) 11.5\(bn (2025E) due to a slowdown in line extensions and following the completion of its network modernization efforts. Our view is summarized by the following key points.
Our 2026/2027 adj. EBITDA estimates are \(\) 22.9bn/\(\) 22.9bn\(vs consensus (per Visible Alpha) of\) \ \(23.2bn /\) \ \(23.4bn\) .

Fixed wireless access (FWA) and competitive fiber builds continue to gain share, limiting cable broadband pricing. We expect FWA subscribers to double by the end of the decade, and we expect fiber passings to nearly double over the next five years with each of the wireless carriers becoming more aggressive on their fiber builds. FWA and fiber competition will continue to pressure Charter's broadband base, limiting subscriber growth. For FWA specifically, we model AT&T+Verizon+T-Mobile subscribers growing from 12 mn in 2024 to 26 mn by the end of 2029. While FWA does not provide premium speeds, it has gained traction in the value segment within both residential and business and there is a place in the market for the product. We are also concerned on pricing growth and believe a mix of smaller fiber operators focused on subscriber growth, higher entry- level speed offers, and exploding offers could together create a headwind on pricing.
Mobile and convergence likely to drive eventual improvements in broadband.

CHTR has 11 mn wireless subscribers (as of 2Q25) and is on track to add 2 mn wireless subscriber net additions in 2025E, making it the second fastest growing wireless phone business only second to T-Mobile. We believe that CHTR's mobile offering is attractively priced relative to the national mobile network operators and should be an effective strategy in improving the price- value perception of CHTR's entire product offering (including broadband) among residential and business customers. We estimate that Charter's residential wireless penetration relative to its broadband subscriber base sits at \(\sim 17\%\) today, and we estimate this will rise to \(27\%\) by the end of 2029.

Streaming apps strategy to improve cord cutting and video ARPU trends, but likely still on a path lower. We laud Charter's innovation in video, which is differentiating itself relative to its competitors. Charter is on track to make several ad- supported streaming apps to its pay TV subscribers for no additional cost, effectively providing \(\sim \$ 100\) of additional retail value through the availability of products such as Disney+ Basic, ESPN+, HBO Max Basic with Ads, Paramount+ Essential, and Peacock Premium. In addition to subscriber trend improvements by providing additional customer value, this should serve as an ARPU growth driver with these services serving as the foundation of a digital store front where Charter can sell ad- free tier upgrades to pay TV subscribers and distribute apps to the company's broadband subscribers (which do not get provisioned for these apps without cost). Although the streaming apps strategy likely will improve cord cutting trends, we continue to forecast residential video subscriber losses of 310- 350k per year (2026- 2028E).

Our 12- month target price of \(\) 223\(reflects 5.5X NTM + 1Y EV / EBITDA. Our target EV/EBITDA multiple is at the low end of CHTR's historical range. We acknowledge valuation, especially on a P/FCF basis, is depressed, but we believe without a hard catalyst the stock will have trouble gaining shareholder interest. We believe if the company can begin to show positive broadband subscriber growth that would drive investors to revisit the name on the long side, but we do not believe valuation itself will be enough for a recovery.

Fixed wireless broadband is likely to prove a more durable competitor over time. We believe cable bulls and cable management teams have downplayed the efficacy and sustainability since the initial rollout of the product at the beginning of the decade. We believe FWA serves a specific segment of the market including low end consumers, single people in apartments, and small businesses where broadband is not key to the business (coffee shops, hair salons, etc.). This segment of the broadband market, which is focused on light- to- moderate usage, continues to gain traction and we forecast FWA subscribers to grow from 12 mn in 2024 to 26 mn by the end of 2029. T- Mobile and Verizon are guiding to 12 mn and 8- 9 mn subs by 2028, respectively, and we expect AT&T to have 4 mn in 2028. With continued network investments and potentially incremental spectrum coming towards the end of the decade, we believe the wireless networks will have enough capacity to handle the incremental demand. Further upside to our estimates could exist if the wireless carriers devote CapEx dollars specifically at
targeting the FWA opportunity.
Exhibit 106: While we expect FWA net additions to slow, we believe FWA will continue to be a formidable broadband competitorWireless carrier FWA net additions (000s)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We estimate that \(\sim 97\%\) of Charter's cable footprint overlaps with fixed wireless service today, up from \(\sim 95\%\) last summer, and this is likely to move higher over time. On a combined basis with the Cox asset, we see FWA offerings in \(\sim 97\%\) of the footprint. Verizon has begun offering its new multi- dwelling unit (MDU) FWA product, and we expect it to target areas outside of its core northeastern footprint.
Exhibit 108: Fixed wireless service overlaps with \(\sim 97\%\) of Charter's service footprint Shading indicates percentage of population served
Source: FCC, Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We expect fiber competition to intensify further. As noted above, we expect fiber passings to nearly double over the next five years. In conjunction with the Lumen fiber asset purchase announcement, AT&T stated that the company expects to expand its targeted fiber passings from \(\sim 30\) mn currently to \(\sim 60\) mn by 2030 given the market opportunity it sees on both the broadband side but also the benefits it receives from

customers who bundle broadband and wireless. Verizon expects to increase its fiber passings from \(\sim 18 \text{mm}\) currently to \(30 \text{m + }\) in 2028 due to organic builds in combination with the pending Frontier acquisition. Verizon notes that, once the Frontier deal closes, it plans to pass \(1 \text{mn + }\) locations per year and is targeting 35- 40mn passings over time. T- Mobile has recently become more aggressive in the fiber space, announcing JVs with Lumos and Metronet in 2024. The company currently passes less than \(1 \text{mn}\) locations on the way 12- 15 mn by 2030. Bell Canada, Uniti, and others are expanding their fiber footprints as well. Given the meaningful overlap of these providers' fiber builds with Charter's service footprint, we expect fiber competition to intensify over time.
Exhibit 109: Fiber providers overlap a meaningful amount of Charter's service footprint Shading indicates percentage of population served
Source: FCC, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Broadband pricing growth likely to decelerate on competition. We believe the next major risk in the broadband story, and for Charter as well, is what happens with broadband pricing. Cable and fiber companies have begun instituting multi- year price locks. We think risk on the pricing front stems from 1) smaller fiber operators, 2) entry- level speed offerings are already plentiful, and 3) exploding offers. We believe the largest is from the smaller, privately owned fiber companies, as we believe these companies are likely focused on subscriber growth first and profitability growth second. Second, entry- level speed tiers have increased materially over the past few years, which we believe could reduce customers self- selecting up the speed curve. Third, cable companies have been using 'exploding' offers whereby the initial price of the service begins at \(30 \text{month}\) (in the case of Charter's 100Mbps plan) and shifts to \(50 \text{month}\) after the first year. We believe these promotional roll offs result in negative goodwill with customers and are likely part of the reason the cable companies have seen customer deflections to FWA and fiber over the past few years. While we haven't seen a reduction in broadband ARPUs, Charter's peer, Comcast, walked away from its broadband ARPU growth target of 3- 4% earlier this year. Notably, CHTR's launch of a streaming video marketplace - including for broadband only subscribers - can help drive potential upside to ARPU to the extent it gains traction.
It remains unclear if wireless is actually helping the broadband business, though

standalone financials are improving. Charter has added \(\sim 2mm\) wireless subscribers per year over the past three years, and we expect solid wireless net additions going forward. Yet, over the same period the company has had no broadband subscriber growth. The company stated at 2Q24 results the mobile business was EBITDA positive though we believe it was likely a \(\) 1bn\(drag on FCF in 2024 overall. We do not model mobile profitability explicitly in our model since the company no longer provides costs or CapEx, but using our current published estimates and making some assumptions, we expect the mobile business may reach close to FCF breakeven in 2025.

Assuming 2.5 people per home, we estimate that Charter's residential wireless penetration relative to its broadband subscriber base sits at \(\sim 17\%\) today and we estimate this will rise to \(27\%\) by the end of 2029. However, while the company notes that wireless is reducing churn in its wireline business, it does not appear to be driving net new customers to the company. We estimate between 2025- 2029, Charter will add \(\sim 9mm\) wireless subscribers while losing more than 1.5mn broadband customers.

Exhibit 110: We expect steady, albeit slowing, residential wireless subscriber growth and rising penetration while we expect broadband growth to remain negativeResidential wireless and broadband net additions and wireless penetration
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We believe Charter's PayTV strategy could drive upside to broadband, however. As noted above, Charter's video strategy has differed from its major cable peer, Comcast. Charter has been adding streaming apps to its bundled lineup, giving customers a material discount compared to purchasing each of the apps individually. While it is too early to know the impact, we believe the company's video strategy could be a better churn reducer or an improved gross add funnel for the broadband business than wireless is.
Charter believes its video package offers offer incremental value to its subscribers, saving consumers \(\sim\) \$100 per month as opposed to purchasing these video applications

on their own. While a limited segment of consumers may demand the full suite of these applications, the telecom companies are not likely to compete with similarly comprehensive bundles in the near term. This positions Charter's offering as a potential differentiator, capable of mitigating broadband customer churn to competitors.

From 4Q19 (first quarter before COVID) through 4Q25, we estimate Charter will cumulatively add \(\sim 625k\) more broadband net additions than Comcast. Charter has invested incrementally into its rural footprint which has added \(\sim 350k\) broadband subscribers since the beginning of 2023 - adjusting broadband net additions for these rural subscribers, we estimate Charter will outperform Comcast by \(\sim 275k\) . Valuation is depressed. We acknowledge valuation, especially on a P/FCF basis, is depressed, but we believe without a hard catalyst the stock will have trouble gaining shareholder interest. We believe if the company can begin to show positive broadband subscriber growth that would drive investors to revisit the name on the long side, but we do not believe valuation itself will be enough for a recovery.

We currently see downside risk to Charter shares based on our view of increasing competitive intensity in the broadband business, driven by the longer- range viability of fixed wireless access and fiber offerings. We could be more positive on CHTR stock under varying scenarios including if:

- The wireless carrier's network reaches a point of congestion where either 1) FWA customers start to churn faster or 2) the carriers stop offering FWA service to new customers. This would improve the competitive dynamic in the industry for Charter and could foreshadow broadband subscriber growth.- The telecom companies pull back on fiber deployment plans, which also would help the competitive dynamic in the market.- Charter is able to show sustained EBITDA growth. Many investors today are skeptical on profitability growth and incremental confidence here would be meaningful. However, EBITDA growth through cost cuts alone is likely a short-term positive but unsustainable over the long-term.- Charter's video strategy shows it can drive incremental broadband churn benefits.

Fixed wireless access could potentially saturate the market faster than we expect, particularly if the pace of net subscriber additions were to slow materially due to limited capacity; Fiber competitors could begin to slow their deployments significantly if they are unable to realize their planned penetration rates or cost per passing, or if they do not receive BEAD funding in some states; Charter could introduce compelling pricing and/or bundled offers which it uses to arrest the rate of broadband subscriber losses.

We assume coverage of Cogent Communications (CCOI) with a Neutral rating and 12- month price target of \(\) 40\(. Cogent provides a variety of commercial fiber access solutions to a range of corporate and enterprise customers. We believe the company continues its pivot to a stronger growth posture post its Sprint wireline acquisition. However, we believe that some of Cogent's long - term opportunities (such as wavelengths transport) are likely to take longer to play out than the Street expects. We believe the Cogent story hinges on top - line performance which has disappointed investors in the past year. Until the company can show improvement in its revenue trajectory, we believe the stock will struggle to outperform. Our view summarized by the following key points.

Wavelengths transport business expected to grow materially, however likely to face headwinds along the way. Cogent is in the process of nurturing its optical wavelength and optical transport services offerings, consisting of shortening its wavelength provisioning timeline and building out its capability to serve more locations within its footprint. Management has targeted \(\) 500\(mn of annualized revenue from wavelength services by 2028, and reported\) \ \(36\) mn of annualized wavelength revenue in 2Q25. While the company has made material progress in developing the product offering, such as enabling wavelength services in 938 locations as of 2Q25 versus 516 locations in 2Q24, we believe wavelengths revenue will accelerate at a slower pace than management currently targets.

Core business growth at risk amid light capital intensity outlook. We believe Cogent's core business of providing fiber service to corporate office buildings will continue to recover slowly, however we believe the company's plan to lower capital intensity (we expect run rate CapEx of \(\) 100\(mn per year relative to 2024 CapEx of\) \ \(195\) mn) could constrain its growth potential. During the COVID pandemic, the core Net- Centric business was negatively impacted by low in- office occupancy rates which are now gradually recovering - and we think the business will remain relatively flat in 2025 and 2026 when excluding revenue from wavelength services. The acquired enterprise business from Sprint will continue to face headwinds from the falloff of non- core, low- margin services which the company seeks to wind down.

Cogent has multiple options to alleviate near- term capital constraints. We believe Cogent would face challenges in covering its CapEx, interest expense, and growing dividend payout with its Adjusted EBITDA in the long run. This may require the company to raise capital, which could come in one of several forms including debt financing (a \(\) 600\(mn offering was completed in June) or an equity raise. Based on management's recent commentary, an asset sale may also be an option. Management called out \~100MW of excess datacenter assets and/or a portion of its excess IPV4 addresses are among the potential candidates, which we believe could help relieve this shortfall.

Our 12- month target price of \(40 reflects 10.0X NTM+1Y EV/EBITDA. Our target EV/EBITDA multiple is toward the lower end of CCOI's historical range given more tepid growth and capital allocation dynamics.

Cogent expects its wavelength business to grow dramatically over the next three years; we believe growth will be more measured over this period. Cogent is constructing a wavelength network using predominantly owned fiber where it is re- purposing a portion of the assets it acquired from Sprint to expand its product offerings to include optical wavelength and optical transport services. As of 2Q25, the company is offering wavelength services in 938 locations and the company has materially shortened its provisioning timeline. Management noted that there will be 10,000 unique wave opportunities in its funnel by the end of 2025 after reporting a backlog of 4,687 wavelength opportunities in 2Q25. Cogent has guided to wavelength revenues reaching an annualized \(\) 500\(mn of revenue\) (\ \(125mn\) of wavelength revenue per quarter) by mid- year 2028. After reporting \(\) 7.1\(mn of wavelengths revenue in 1Q25, the company reported\) \ \(9.1\) mn of wavelengths revenue in 2Q25. To reach its target, this would imply a \(\sim 106\%\) four- year revenue CAGR from 2024YE to 2028YE. We think it will take longer than management currently expects for revenue to accelerate materially, and we estimate an \(\sim 87\%\) revenue four- year CAGR as a result.
Exhibit 116: Our forecasts are below Cogent's 2028 target of \(\) 500\(mn run - rate annualized revenue from wavelengths GSe vs Cogent guidance's implied wavelength revenue through 2028
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Cogent's revenue and EBITDA growth is outpacing wireline peers, while capital investment lags. Relative to enterprise wireline businesses at AT&T, Verizon, and Lumen, Cogent's revenue and EBITDA trends are strongest - we believe Cogent's revenue will grow high single digits in 2026 and beyond after getting through some short term connections headwinds throughout 2025. However, outside of wavelength services, we see limited tailwinds in the business. Corporate revenue growth is

stagnating as work- from- home policies remain prevalent across the United States, causing elevated office vacancy rates to persist. Since Cogent took on Sprint's Enterprise business as part of the 2023 acquisition, connections, and subsequently revenue, have steadily declined. We believe Enterprise connection declines will continue in the medium term as the company grows ARPU to stabilize revenue trends.

Cogent management has stated that it expects capital expenditures (excluding capital lease payments) to decline to a \(\) 25m\(per quarter run - rate from current levels (an average of\) \ \(57m\) in 1H25). This will put them at a significantly lower capital intensity (GSe \(Exhibit 117: Cogent's revenue growth should be largely driven by wavelength offerings and Net-Centric Cogent annual revenue by segment through 2028E (\$, mn)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 118: Lumen is investing more capital into its business Cogent versus Lumen capital intensity through 2028 (capex as a percentage of revenue, \%)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

While lower capital expenditures are a near- term help, the current capital allocation appears unsustainable. In Exhibit 119, we show a simplified free cash flow calculation (EBITDA - interest expense - cash taxes - CapEx). While this results in a positive simple FCF, Cogent still needs to take on leverage to pay out its \(\sim\) 200mn dividend, which the company has continued to grow sequentially over the past 10 years.

In addition to keeping its balance sheet highly levered, Cogent could optimize its balance sheet through asset sales. Management has called out for asset sales a portfolio of one million square footage of excess data center capacity with a power surplus of \(100+\) MW that the company is modernizing. While telecom datacenters have been relatively unattractive targets for datacenter operators due to their dated infrastructure and limited capacity, we believe there could be a place in the market for Cogent's datacenters due to the scarcity of power supply provided by the traditional grid, increasing the demand for less traditional assets. While we do not take a view on the potential value of these assets, nor do our estimates reflect any potential transactions, we believe that any asset
sale the company is able to execute would improve its short- term capital needs.

- Cogent may experience pressure to its cost structure, driving slower EBITDA growth and lower free cash flow;- Cogent's focus on driving wavelength sales may not be successful or may take longer than expected;- Cogent may take longer than expected to complete the wind-down of low-quality revenues in its core business;- Cogent's free cash flow does not adequately cover its dividend.

We assume coverage of Lumen Technologies (LUMN) with a Neutral rating and a 12- month target price of \(4.10. Lumen is a large- scale provider of both enterprise wireline and consumer fiber services. The company is in the process of a multi- step business turnaround which involves focusing the business on enterprise services, the proposed sale of its consumer fiber business to AT&T, de- levering the balance sheet, cost savings initiatives, and improving its go- to- market focus in support of new service offerings. We have low levels of conviction given ongoing revenue declines with management targeting 2029 as the year revenue inflects positively. We want to have more confidence revenue can grow before becoming incrementally more bullish on the stock. Lumen will hold an Investor Day in February 2026 where we expect new revenue disclosures (products vs. segments), an update on the cost transformation, and a capital allocation update including leverage expectations and free cash flow. Our view is summarized by the following key points.

Revenue pressure is likely to continue, though hyperscaler connectivity plans should drive turnaround over time. Lumen generates about 1/2 of its Business revenue from mature or legacy offerings (e.g., Nurture, Harvest) and we believe these should continue to decline double- digits as the company focuses its efforts on next- generation products and services. LUMN has demonstrated traction in more solutions- based products such as Private Connectivity Fabric (PCF) and Network- as- a- Service (NaaS), while winning deals with hyperscalers to provide dark fiber for data center connectivity capacity. Legacy revenue likely will dictate the overall trajectory of the business in the near- to- mid- term. We forecast revenue to decline \(6\%\) yoy in 2025E with LUMN expecting revenue declines to improve in 2026E and to return to growth by 2029E (GSe: \(+1\%\) ).

EBITDA and free cash flow stabilizing on cost initiatives and working capital. LUMN is on track to realize \(\) 1\(bn of total cost savings by year - end 2027, including\) \ \(350\) mn of run- rate synergies realized by year- end 2025. LUMN's EBITDA likely will trough during 2025E, before returning to growth in 2026E - achieving its goal of at least \(\) 3.5\(bn of EBITDA in 2026E. We believe that, in spite of revenue pressure, the company is taking the right actions to stabilize EBITDA and FCF trends by focusing on cost reduction in legacy product areas while continuing to fund growth initiatives.

Mass Markets potential sale could help de- levering. On May 21, AT&T announced that it has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Lumen's Mass Markets fiber asset in a cash transaction valued at \(\) 5.75\(bn. A successful sale of these assets should reduce LUMN's net leverage (per company guidance) and allow the company to focus on its core Business services.

Our 12- month target price of \(\) 4.10\$ reflects 5.5X NTM+1Y EV/EBITDA. Our target EV/EBITDA multiple is near the midpoint of LUMN's historical range given the growth potential in time, industry competition factors, and capital allocation
dynamics as outlined above.

Lumen (and the broader enterprise fiber industry) have long been focused on revenue stabilization, which has proven challenging. We believe it will take time for Lumen's top line to stabilize. We expect the company's mid- market business could continue to be disrupted by fixed wireless, and note that Lumen has been losing significant market share in this segment for many years. On the enterprise side, this segment remains fiercely competitive as we believe cable (including Comcast specifically) is looking to compete upmarket as the SMB/mid- market segments become saturated and more competitive. For instance, AT&T is guiding its Business Wireline segment EBITDA to decline in the low- double- digit range, and Verizon has noted that \(6\% - 8\%\) revenue declines are the average in its Business Wireline segment.

Given the level of Al connectivity demand, Lumen management cited at least \(\) 12bn\(of Al deals in its current pipeline (\) \ \(9bn\) in signed deals as of 2Q25). In comparing the company's network map alongside Microsoft's operational datacenters as an example of Lumen's target customer for its PCF deals, we highlight that almost all of Microsoft's existing datacenters are passed within \(\sim 200\) miles of Lumen's existing fiber router. We believe that there is likely incremental industry- wide opportunity to benefit from emerging Al connectivity opportunities over the next three to five years as hyperscalers accelerate their datacenter builds and connectivity to support them.

Exhibit 120: Microsoft's datacenters are largely in close proximity to Lumen's fiber network, which we believe can explain how Lumen secured connectivity fabric deals. However, enterprise fiber competitors are increasingly expanding their footprint Microsoft datacenter locations are denoted in red, dot size by MW, overlaid with Lumen's US fiber routes

Cost takeout is a key focus for 2025. We believe the optimization of Lumen's cost base is a key management priority for 2025. If the company is able to successfully right- size its cost structure, it should ultimately provide the basis for operating leverage as the company attempts to stabilize - and ultimately grow - revenue. Management has already gone through a number of cost savings exercises, namely a \(300 mn annualized cost savings program in 2023, and another\) 300 mn program that completed in 3Q24. The company has guided to an incremental \(1 bn of run- rate cost savings by the end of 2027, although we note that the remaining cost takeout opportunities may be harder to extract than what has been achieved thus far. Management is also focused on de- levering the balance sheet and reducing interest expense over time.

could help to reduce leverageAT&T announced that is has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Lumen's Mass Markets fiber asset in a cash transaction valued at \(5.75 bn. This equates to a transaction price per fiber passing of - \$1,300 - \$1,400, as per management's calculation. As discussed in several past earnings calls and conference appearances, management has stated that it doesn't believe it has the right to win in consumer wireline, and that this business fits best with a strategic partner that is looking to continue investing in its fiber business or build a converged broadband plus mobile product. Lumen management notes that, while this asset generates \$100- 200 mn of EBITDA, the company has been investing - \$1bn per year of capex in its Mass Market segment. In addition, the proposed deal (if consummated) would allow Lumen to reduce debt by \$4.8bn, thereby decreasing interest expense by \$300mn - resulting in an overall cash flow positive impact of \$1.3bn according to management.

- Lumen could execute better on cost takeouts, driving margins, and EBITDA higher than consensus forecasts;- Revenue stabilization could come sooner than expected and this, coupled with improved margins, could drive significant upside to EBITDA and FCF forecasts;- A significant change in capital structure could be a material positive for the equity.

- Lumen could find that incremental cost takeout opportunities are more difficult to achieve than currently expected;- Business fiber's structural headwinds may continue to limit Lumen's ability to turnaround revenue for longer;- Lumen could encounter fiercer competition from industry peers for incremental private connectivity fabric deals, limiting its ability to restructure.

Frontier is a regional broadband provider which is pivoting to fiber service from its traditional base of legacy wireline service. The company has been aggressively building fiber across its footprint and now has \(8.5mm\) passings. Frontier has been able to pivot the company from legacy top- and bottom- line declines with revenue and adjusted EBITDA growing \(\sim 4\%\) and \(\sim 7\%\) Y/Y in 1H25. The company announced in 2024 that it agreed to be acquired by Verizon for \(38.50 per share. The deal is slated to close in 1Q26. On a fundamental basis, we expect Frontier to report solid operating results including continued strong fiber net additions.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.
